text: The dormitory of the section gang. The men are through fo lounging on their bunkbeds. DUFF ANDERSON plays checkers bottle tops as pieces. Duff makes the winning move and Fr turns over the board. He saunters over to JOCKO, who is s mirror. Frankie watches him with a grin.
Go to hell, Frankie.
Man, you sure one ugly cat! He takes the cigarettes Jocko has rolled, sailor-style, i his T-shirt.
Why don't you guys buy your own?
'Oughta give up smoking, Jocko. He stops in front of an older man, who is writing a lette
How much longer we got on this stretch, Riddick?
Five weeks, maybe six.
Man, what a dump. He circles restlessly past two cardplayers back to Duff, fingernails.
What you gettin' all pretty for?
(with a grin)  Why don't you relax, Frankie?
Duff, Frankie, and Jocko are riding a track-car, powered into the nearest town. The sun is setting. A church bell
Jocko, a cigar in his mouth, is playing a pinball machine stand at the bar. They are joined by DORIS , a sad-lookin skin.
Who's going to buy me a beer?
(scornfully)  What's the matter, Doris? Business bad?
It sure is.
Everybody givin' it away free, huh?
You gonna buy me a beer, Frankie?
See Duff. He's the money man.
What d'you say, Duff?
(to the bartender)  Give her a beer.
Thanks, Duff. You' a nice guy. Not like Frankie.
You know, Doris - you'd make some guy a swell  wife.
You think so, Frankie?
Hell, you got steady work.
Quit ridin' her, Frankie. The bartender serves her a bottle of beer
I ain't ridin' her. Wouldn't ride her on a bet. Duff pays for the beer and turns to leave.
Where' you goin'?
Out.
Want me to come?
No thanks.
Come on, honey.
Where' you goin'?
'Round town.
What's so hot 'round town?
(with a grin)  Take it easy, Frankie. He leaves.
Don't wanna fish you outa no jailhouse. STREET (Night) Duff is walking along the deserted street in the black pa Music from the pool hall fades and we pick up the strains from a nearby church.

The choir is singing "Precious Lord." The women are spiri congregation in the small wooden building is alive to the Duff appears in the open doorway and stops to listen. When the song ends, REVEREND DAWSON rises from his chair.

I'm glad to see this meeting off to a good  start. Now we'll take a break and then come back  to hear from our distinguished guest - Reverend  Butler of the Morgan Street Baptist Church in  Birmingham. See you all in a little while. Reverend Butler compliments him on the choir.
Long tables laden with food are lit by strings of lightbu gospel piano from inside the church. A smiling middle-aged woman has taken Duff in tow and lea young woman (JOSIE), who is serving food.

Josie - this is Brother Anderson. Now you give  him some of that good food. He's a fine young  man.  (on her way)  Ain't it a wonderful meetin'?! Duff studies Josie with a smile. She is clearly middle cl food on a paper plate, she glances at him - matching his with her own. She hands him the plate
Thank you, Ma'am. That's fine.
You must be new in town.
(with a grin)  I'll have me some of that punch there, too. She serves the punch.
Haven't seen you around, have I?
No. I'm new in town.
(unwilling to give up)  You working?
Yeah. On the section gang. He is sure that this will put a stop to her curiosity. It
(interested)  Oh yeah?
You work around town?
I'm a teacher.
Went to college, huh?
In Birmingham.
Oh yeah? That's my home town.
Your folks live there?
No. My mother's dead. (after a moment) You goin' back inside?
Yes, aren't you?
No. Never had much use for hell-howlers. You  goin'?
(with a smile)  My father's the preacher.
(grinning)  Oh yeah? Well, I guess you got no choice.
That's right.
(a bit tentatively)  Look, I don't know what you been told 'bout  section gangs, but how 'bout seein' me sometime?
(with a non-committal smile)  Maybe.

The visiting revival preacher is in full swing, preaching congregation of women is in a state of high excitement. J of it, though she sits in their midst. Duff has been standing in the doorway. He turns away.
Duff walks away, past a shack. The singing fades. A dog b BUNK CAR (Night)  Duff, Frankie, Jocko, and an older man (POP) are playing for his turn, Jocko catches a fly and sneaks a look at Fr
You got a lousy hand, Frankie. Frankie throws down the cards.
Yeah, I quit. He gets up. At loose ends, he picks up an old Flit-gun an Duff, who is polishing his shoes.
You got nothin' on your mind but your hair,  Frankie. How 'bout your car, Riddick?
Yeah, you can have it.
Man, you won't like that back seat.
Man, why 'you messin' around with a gal like  that? You won't get no place.
Hell, they're all after the same thing.
Yeah. All a colored woman wants is your money.
What d'you know about women, Pop?
Well, I got married to one of them.
Hell, I didn't know you was married.
Sure. Got a sixteen-year-old girl.
Is that right?  (to Duff)  Think you're gonna make it with her?
Just get her drunk.
(to Riddick)  How 'bout the key?
I bet she's easy jam. DAWSON DINING ROOM (Night) A middle-class tableau. Dinner is over. Reverend Dawson i Josie, dressed for an evening out, sits across from her s looking at her with pursed lips.
I know you pay no mind to my feelings, but  d'you think it's right for you to go out with  him?
I'm twenty-six years old, Susan.
Perhaps you ought to tell her, Frank. Reverend Dawson has no stomach for confrontations, but tu dutifully.
Well, we have a position in town, Josie. You  have to remember that. There're lots of other  young men.
I don't think your mother would have approved.
I do.
Well, there's just one thing you can be looking  for in a man like that.
I know that's what you think.
Hush your mouth, child. The doorbell rings.
(leaving the table)  Good night, Dad.
On the dimly lit, smoke-hung floor a large crowd is danci a great time. When the music ends, she and Duff return to
That's pretty good for a preacher's daughter.
What d'you expect?
You know, baby, I can't figure you out.
How d'you mean?
Why d'you come out with me? You slummin' or  something?
No.
So what you doin' with a cat like me in a joint  like this?
You don't think much of yourself, do you?
(put off)  Well, that's a funny thing to say.
You keep asking me why I'm here.
Yeah, and you keep not answerin', too.
I like a place with lots of life.
How about another beer?
No thanks.
Go on - you can have one! His attention is drawn by something off screen.
Hell!
What is it? Frankie and Jocko swagger toward them, beer in hand.
Well, if it ain't Duff!
How you doin'? (to Josie; with  a bit of a leer) Hi there!
Hi.
Mind if we sit down?
We was just leavin', fellows.
Let's go, Jocko. The man's got homework.
(leaving)  See you, Duff.
Yeah, see you in hell. Frankie follows Jocko out of the frame.
They must work on the section gang.
That's right.
Well, they seem just like everyone else.
Hell, baby, I bet you think we got tails.
(off-screen)  We do! Frankie and Jocko have occupied the adjoining table and a Duff gets up, camouflaging his irritation.
Come on, baby. He ushers Josie out. Frankie looks after them.
School teacher! My nappy head! INT. RIDDICK'S OLD CONVERTIBLE (Night) Duff has parked on a country road.
I guess it's hard working on the road like that.
Damn few places you can make eighty bucks a  week.
I mean, you're kind of cut off, aren't you?
That's fine with me. Keeps me out of trouble.
How d'you mean?
Well, I don't get on so well most places.
I see. That beer made me dizzy. Duff is looking at her.
You got a lovely face, kid. Ain't too often I  get to meet a girl like you. Hell-- He kisses her, but releases her very quickly.
Baby, how many times' you been kissed? Josie takes a moment to collect herself.
Well, let's see now - not counting tonight ...  must be about twenty-eight times.
(with a grin)  You got a problem all right. Someone moves in back of her. A white man in his early tw from the dark and looks down at them.
(with a smile)  Hi. The voice of a second white man calls from off screen.
They doin' anything?
(calling back)  Nah, nothin'!
Get out of here!
(frightened)  Don't Duff--
Relax, man! The second white man joins him.
What's goin' on? He shines his flashlight into Duff's face.
Cut that out! The white man shines the flashlight across Josie's breast
(very tense)  I said: Cut it out!
Don't start no trouble, boy!
Let's go! That's the preacher's girl. Mess with  him and you got old man Johnson on your back.  Come on. The white men leave.
Let's go, Duff.
Take it easy. We see that he has a knife in his hand. He closes and poc The white men drive off, whooping and beating on the side
Don't sound human, do they? INT. MOVING CAR (Night) Duff is driving through the center of town.
How come you stay 'round here?
Well, my mother was the only good teacher the  colored school ever had. Nobody bothers with  those kids.
That's why you come back, huh?
It's hard to see any change. But I'm going to  stay. Another year, anyway.
You got more guts than me, baby. It's a no-good  town.
It's better than it used to be. Eight years ago  they still had a lynching here. They tied a man  to a car and dragged him to death. My father  knew who did it, but he didn't say anything.
Scared, huh? The car pulls up in front of the Dawson house and Duff pa
Well, good night, baby. He is about to kiss her.
Not here, Duff.
I get it. (with a laugh) Yeah, I can see your old man with a shot-gun  right now.
But I would like to see you again.
You would, huh? If I was you, baby - I wouldn't  go 'round stickin' out my jugular vein.
What d'you mean?
You almost got into trouble back there.
(with a smile)  I wouldn't have let you.
Hell, baby, I'm not in the third grade. Well,  look - what' we gonna do next time -- have a  nice long chat in the parlor?
No, on the porch.
Oh yeah, and then what?
What?
Well, either we're gonna hit the hay or get  married. Now you don't want to hit the hay, and  I don' want to get married.
You have some very primitive ideas, don't you?
(defensively)  All right, so I'm primitive. So what d'you want  with me?

Look, Duff - most of the men I know - they're  kind of sad. When I met you the other day I had  a feeling that you're different. That's why I  went out with you. I thought we might have  something to say to each other.
Hell, baby, I don't know what to say.
Good night, Duff. She gets out of the car and starts toward the house. He looks after her, then drives away.
The section hands are hunting rabbits, scaring them up ou and then clubbing them with sticks that have a heavy bolt Jocko is fishing from a trestle. Pop fries skinned rabbit is whittling.
The grade school children, all black, are writing at thei The end-of-school bell rings and one of the boys jumps up
Are you finished, Jackie?
Yes, Ma'am.
Well, I'm not. Wait till class is dismissed. She walks over to close the window. In the yard below, Duff is sitting on one of the swings. Josie smiles and turns to the kids --
All right. Class dismissed.
A bus crowded with noisy kids pulls away to reveal the ya are sitting on two swings side by side.
At first it was real strange. Hell, Japan is a  long ways from Alabama. Really got under my  skin, though. Almost didn't come back.
Why did you?
I don't know. 'Guess I belong here more than  there.
'Been up north?
Yeah. Knocked around for a couple of months  after the Army. You been there?
No.
Well, it ain't that good up there neither. Might  as well make it here. 'Course I ain't really  makin' it now. He gets up and gives her swing a forceful shove.
Anyway, they can't get to you if you keep movin'! Josie laughs.
It is raining. Duff and Josie dash up the path to the fro
Duff and Josie barge in out of the rain and find themselv Reverend Dawson and a middle-aged white man - Superintend
Oh, I'm sorry.
Come on in, Josie. We're all through.
Daddy - this is Duff Anderson.
Hello.
How are you?
All right, son.
This is Mr. Johnson, our school superintendent.
(with a friendly smile)  How are you?
I'll be right back. She leaves.
So you're courtin' the preacher's girl. Well,  just watch your step, boy, or he'll preach you  right into hell.  (to Reverend Dawson)  I'm counting on you, Reverend.
I understand.
Wouldn't do for one of your people to sue at a  time like this.
I know.
(on his way out)  I'll talk to the Mayor.
That'll make the folks very happy. Johnson leaves. Reverend Dawson sits down in a rocker.
It's hard to know how to talk to the white folks  these days.
Guess it's never been easy.
It's a changing time. Sit down, son.
Thank you. He sits down opposite Reverend Dawson.
Well, it looks like we'll be getting our new  school.
How come you all ain't sendin' them to the same  school?
Well, you've got to go easy. We haven't had any  trouble in town for eight years, and we're not  going to have any now.
Can't live without trouble, can you?  (he sees he is on  the wrong track)  Nice place you got here. Real nice.
Yes, the Lord's been pretty good to us. I  guess you're a church man, aren't you?
I guess I ain't.
Why? Don't you believe in the Lord?
Aw, I do. But 'seems to me us colored folks do  a whole lot of church-goin'. It's the whites  that need it real bad.
I think if you tried livin' in a town like this,  instead of running free and easy, you'd soon  change your tune.
I doubt it.
I see.  (rising)  Well, I guess we don't have much to say to each  other.
I guess not.
And since we're talking, my wife and I don't  want you hanging around our daughter.
Well, that figures.  (he too stands up)  Kind of fits in with everything else, don't it!
Duff comes out. Josie joins him a moment later.
I'm sorry.
Ain't your fault.
That's the way he is.
Yeah. It's just like I figured.
What d'you mean?
Hell, I don't belong here. I don't know what I' been thinkin'.
Look, Duff - if you're free, I'm not working  tomorrow.
Sorry, baby. I'm goin' to Birmingham.
Just for the day?
Goin' to see my kid.
I didn't know you had one.
Yeah. Well, I do.
Are you married?
No, I ain't married. (leaving) Well, good-bye. COURTHOUSE SQUARE (Morning sunshine) A bus has pulled in.
Duff is making his way down the aisle. To his surprise, h who is sitting at a window with an empty seat next to her
(with a grin)  Well, what-do-you-know?
Surprised?
No. Women're always followin' me 'round.
I'm just going in to do my shopping.
Yeah, it's just a coincidence.
That's right.
(moving on)  I'll see you later.
Come here, Duff. No point running away from  coincidence. He sits down next to her.
Baby, you must be crazy. The bus starts up.
How old is your boy?
Four.
What's he like?
I ain't seen him in a couple of years.
Duff is walking past crowded back-porches in a black sect music. He steps up onto one of the porches and knocks at the scr
Through the screen door we see EFFIE SIMMS, a woman in he sitting on a chair and cradles a sleeping child.
'You Effie Simms?
(suspiciously)  What d'you want?
Guess you must be lookin' after my boy. I'm  Duff Anderson.
'Bout time you showed. Door's open. Duff enters.
(calling)  James Lee, you come in here and meet your daddy.
Where's Wilma?
She done moved to Detroit.
Ain't she goin' to take the boy?
She got herself a husband now. They don' want  him 'round. And I tell you, man, I got no use  for him neither.
I been sendin' her money.
Well, she never gave me none. Look, you better  find him a place pretty quick.
Like where?
I don't know. He's your boy.
I ain't so sure of that. If I was, maybe I'd  feel different. Effie gives him a scornful look, puts down the child, and that leads into the bedroom.
(sharply)  James Lee - I said for you to come in here.
Two children are playing on the floor. James Lee is up on convertible. Duff appears beside Effie in the doorway.
How 'you been, boy? James Lee looks at him, scared and silent.
Go on. Tell him. She returns to the parlor.
I got you something. He crouches down and holds out a toy. James Lee approache and withdraws.
Effie is folding diapers. Duff comes out of the bedroom.
'Doctor says he could use some shots.
Yeah. Look, I'll be sendin' you the money from  now on.
Okay.
Make sure he gets those shots. He looks back at the boy in the bedroom.
They say your dad's 'round town.
'That right? I thought he was up North.
People seen him 'round.
Where's he at?
I don't know.
Duff is walking through a black section of town.
Duff climbs to the top of the rickety wooden steps.
Duff's father, a big man in his fifties, is reclining on Duff appears in the open doorway.
'You Will Anderson?
Who're you?
I'm Duff.
(sitting up, with  a faint grin)  Wouldn't have known you.
Wouldn't have known you.
What's on your mind?
Nothing. Heard you were in town.
Wanted a look at your old man, huh?
Yeah. That's right. Will gets up and crosses the room.
How about a drink?
Okay. Will pours whiskey into two glasses. Duff sees that Will' empty.
What happened?
Workin' a saw mill. (raising his glass) Here's to. A woman in her late thirties (LEE) comes in with a shoppi
Baby - want you to meet Duff.
(flatly)  Hi.
He's my son! She turns and looks at Duff with a glimmer of interest.
Come and have some coffee. (sitting down) I'm Lee. Sit down. He joins her.
Come on, Will.
What's the matter?! You mad at me?
No. Why?

(sitting down)  Nothin'.  (to Duff)  She's all right. Wouldn't have made it without  her. Christ - haven't worked in eight months.  Right now, I'm waitin' for some insurance money.  And man, when I get it, I got plans to make me  some more.  (he gets up restlessly)  Let's get out'a here. This place gives me the  willies. (to Lee) You got some money?
(she knows what's coming)  Let's stay here, Will.
(aggressively)  What's the matter?! It's a celebration!
Will, Lee, and Duff are standing at the bar. Will has bee
So what's this about a woman? You got woman  trouble?
I said, I come to town with a girl.
Plannin' on getting married?
No.
'Don't sound so sure.
Well, matter of fact, I done a lot of bangin'  'round.
Yeah. That's how me an' your mother got started.  I'm tellin' you, boy, you ain't got a chance  without dough. They take it all away from you. He drains his glass and puts it down for Lee to refill.
Pour your own trouble, Will.
Your mother used to lay for her boss, boy. Did you know that?
Shut up, Will.

Okay, so what's a girl supposed to do? Me not  workin' and her cleanin' house for a white man.  I'm tellin' you, boy, keep away from marriage.  Ya gotta stay light on your feet or you won't  make it. He puts his hand on Lee's bare arm.
Is she good in the hay? No point marryin' her  just to find out. Is there, baby?
If you don't quit it, Will, I'm leaving.
You're breaking my heart. (he grabs her neck  and shakes her) Got to see a man about a dog.
Duff and Lee are dancing. She looks at him with a touch o
Don't let him get you, Duff.
How often does he get like that?
Whenever he's got an edge on.
How often is that?
He's been hitting it pretty hard. Got high  blood pressure, too. I guess it's hard on him,  having you around.
Will is back and drinking when Duff and Lee come off the
(aggressively)  Well, what d'you think of her? Duff says nothing.
I asked you somethin', boy!
I heard you.
Pretty good for a one-armed nigger, huh?
Great.
What d'you want anyhow? What you come and  bother me for?
He's your son.
Okay, boy, beat it.
I got the point. He leaves money on the bar.
Come back some other time, will you?
Yeah, sure. Good luck. DOWNTOWN STREET (Night) Duff is walking, lost in thought. INT. BUS DEPOT (Night) Josie enters with her purchases. She joins Duff at the sa
Hi.
(relieved to see her)  I thought you wasn't comin'. She sits down.
How did it go?
What?
Your boy.
Okay, I guess.
(to off-screen waitress)  I'll have some coffee, please.
You know, I been thinkin' - how 'bout us gettin'  married? Josie is stunned.
(playing for time)  What d'you mean?
Just what I said. Don't look so scared. The waitress puts down a cup of coffee.
Thank you.
How about it?
What happened, Duff?
Look, baby - I don't know 'bout you, but it's  the right thing for me. I just know it is. So,  what d'you say?
Don't push me, Duff.
Yeah. Wouldn't be no picnic for you. I ain't  exactly housebroken.
What about that girl?
She don't mean nothin' to me. That's all over. (after a moment) Hell, baby - I'm askin' you to marry me. I  guess you want a big scene, huh?
No. But a small one. They look at each other.
It's yes, huh? INT. BUNK CAR (Day) Frankie is looking scornfully at Duff, who is lying on hi
I'll be a monkey's kid sister! What d'you want  to do a thing like that for?
'Musta knocked her up.
What're you gonna get out of it, huh?
(with a smile)  A whole lot, Frankie.
(aggressively)  Like what?
Like a home, for one thing.
You gonna sit at home the rest of your life?  Jesus!
Well, it's better than windin' up like a bum.
(defensively)  What 'you signifyin'?
I wasn't thinkin' about you, Frankie.
Ol' Doris sure goin' to miss you.
Just give him a couple of months. A girl like  that, she don't know any tricks.
You know what Doris told me? She say: That  Duff's a nice guy. Wouldn't even charge him  nothin'.
I guess you'll be quittin' the railroad, huh,  man?
That's right.
Man, you must be plumb outa your mind! You'll  be makin' twen'y bucks a week, if you're lucky.
Josie is next to Duff. They are driving past a row of sma in the black section of town.
Turn here. There it is! They stop in front of a house. It is barely larger than a
Duff and Jose come in. The room is full of abandoned, bro the ceiling and wallpaper hang down in strips.
I used to know them. They've gone North.
(with a laugh)  I can see why.
Well, what d'you think?
It's okay with me, baby. But how' you goin' to  like it?
It'll be fine when we get done with it.
Duff is looking out through the broken pane of glass.
Who's that?
A woman is putting laundry into a washing machine on the children are all around her and in the yard below.
Josie has stopped next to Duff and looks out.
That's Bessie Hall. Barney works at the mill.
Yeah? Josie removes a shard of glass from the window; a larger
Hey, watch out! Guess you want a house full of  pickaninnies too, huh?
Don't call them that.
That's all right with me. Always liked kids. He moves to the rear of the room.
Josie turns to him.
What about your boy?
(defensively)  What about him?
He could live with us.
Let's just see how the two of us make out  first, huh?

Duff and Josie are getting married. Duff is waiting near section hands are seated on one side of the aisle, Josie' on the other. The gospel piano segues into the wedding ma down the aisle by herself. She joins Duff and they step f Reverend Dawson. DUFF AND JOSIE'S BEDROOM (Early morning)  Josie lies in bed with closed eyes. She hears Duff move a is dressed for work.
Good luck, baby. He sits down beside her for a moment.
Duff is in the rear seat with his new neighbor, Barney.  Joe, a millhand, sits next to the driver in front. He tur
Hard to get up in the morning, huh?
(with a grin)  That's right. How' you doin', Barney?
(not given to saying much)  Okay.
The car drives up and Joe leans out.
Come on, Willie! Willie, a big man, has been fixing his front step.
Just a minute, man.
Come on - we're late!
(taking his time)  Yazzuh, Boss - ah's comin' as fast as ah can. He picks up his lunch box and shuffles toward the car, St
(laughing)  Get in the car, man!
Willie climbs in next to Duff.
How' you doing, man?
Okay. (to the driver) Let's go.
That's right, Jethro - take us to the plant.  And hurry, boy - ah's got a heavy day. The driver backs up fast, jerking the passengers forward.
Ah tells you, man - you give these niggers a  machine and they go stark-ravin' wild! Laughter.
Duff is among the mill hands punching in on the time cloc
(off screen)  You new here?
That's right.
Duff and two other men are working on top of a pile of lu A white supervisor on a forklift has been watching them.
(calling)  Hey, Jack! Duff doesn't respond.
Hey, boy - I'm talkin' to you.
(after a moment)  Name's Duff.
How 'you doing?
Okay.
(genially)  Looks like you're doin' a good job.
Thanks.
Don't say much, do you?
Guess I don't.
Just so you do your work.
The mill hands are on their lunch break. The only white m looking at Duff with a grin.
Hell, I bet those black girls really go for you,  huh? That's the best-lookin' colored girl in  town. Duff is eating and says nothing.
What's the matter? Still on your honeymoon,  huh? Just like you, Barney. 'Been on your  honeymoon for twen'y years, huh?
(cautiously)  Yeah. The white mill hand helps himself to a piece of Barney's
How many kids you got now, Barney?
Four.
(eating the pie)  Hmmm - she can cook,too. Man, it's no wonder you  'been draggin' your tail on the job. You 'been  doin' your best work at home. He notices that Duff's face is set.
(aggressively)  What's the matter, boy? Never smile?
I'll smile when it's funny.
So it wasn't funny, huh? Well, I thought it was.  What d'you say, Barney? Wasn't it funny?!
Yeah, it was funny.
Sure.  (to the others)  What d'you say, boys? Wasn't it funny?
Yeah. Sure.
(to Duff)  Trouble with you, boy, you ain't got no sense  of humor. Ought to smile more.
I know.
You' new here, man!  (he gets up to leave)  See you, boys.
(to Duff after a moment)  You know, man, that guy was trying to be  friendly.
That ain't my idea of friendliness.
You got to watch yourself pretty close.
Yeah, you want to get along, act the nigger.
Like hell. You know, if you fellows stuck  together 'stead of letting them walk all over  you, they might not try it.
Like hell they wouldn't.
They been doin' it all my life.
Maybe it's time you stopped letting them. Jesse, a heavy-set man who has been silent till now, stan Duff.
Man, you sound like a trouble man. EXT. DUFF AND JOSIE'S HOUSE (Dusk) The lights are on inside.
